title: Water Bottle
content: I have a Knights water bottle that says Fuller on it.

title: 1905: The Foreshock
content:
University riots in Moscow, Petrograd, Warsaw, Kiev
Plehve blamed Jews for the revolutionary tension
Plehve assassinated with bomb
Russia lost a war to Japan, first European power to lose to Asia
Bloody Sunday happened where 40 people killed by police, but hundreds more in other massacres
Hundreds of thousands of workers striking
Union of Unions was the main one
The October Manifesto was the result of all this, created the Duma which didn't have any real power over the monarchy
However, some constitutional reforms were also made moving away from full autocracy

title: Official Russia
content:
The Autocrat was ruler
Russian peasants didn't want civil and political rights, they wanted a strong Russia
In 19th century, weak autocrats were succeeded by strong ones, and strong autocrats by weak ones
Nicholas II displayed signs of being one of the weak ones
The Judiciary in Russia had independent decision making from the autocrat, began 1864
Ministry of Interior was the most important
Russia had remarkable industrial growth from 1890 - 1900
Their army is what made Russia a great European power
1861 emancipation split land ownership 50/50 between dvoriane and serfs
The Church was cultural link for 80 million in Russia
The Church was financially dependent on the government

title: Rural Russia
content:
Peasants were 4/5 of Russians
Government influence on rural Russians was minimal
The household was the base of rural Russia
Individual households were rare, most were in villages
61.8% of the arable land was owned by peasants communally or privately
On the eve of the 1917 revolution it had increased to 9/10
Pre-emancipation the land was cultivated half by the landlord and the other half by the serf
Post-emancipation when property lines were drawn, serfs lost rights to graze cattle, and gather lumber
Only 2 out of 15 million sq. km were arable in Russia
Peasants' lives were self sufficient and self contained
Russian peasants were not concerned with the world outside of their village and neighboring villages
The peasant didn't regard serfdom as intolerable and unjust
They identified with and were proud of their masters
"We are yours, but the land is ours", was often quoted
Growing literacy that was unused contributed to the restlessness of the lower class

title: The Intelligentsia
content:
Intelligentsia are social activists, intellectuals
They were opposition to Tsarism
Believed some kind of determinism, where peasants' ideologies were merely a result of their surroundings
Believed in changing the surroundings of peasants, via legislation for a new order (opinion-molding)
Intelligentsia held comparable ideas to the Jacobins that fueled the French Revolution
Trotsky believed they were making a new, heightened, human being
Believed they were part of a higher historical purpose which justified the violence
Materialism, utilitarianism, and positivism were the ideologies of the Intelligentsia
The Intelligentsia believed they had the right to decide what was good for the peasants
Socialist Revolutionaries divided the people into two groups: Exploiters and Exploited

title: The Constitutional Experiment
content:
For the first time in the hundreds of years of monarchy the Duma had some (very limited) power
Stolypin was the PM and Minister of Interior
Played a major role in calming things down after the 1905 rev.
Many attempts on Stolypin's life occurred
Tried to combat terror with death sentences ("Stolypin Neckties")
He took repressive measures against acts of terror, nearly 1000 death sentences were carried out in 1907
Private land ownership was controversial
Most peasants owned land communally within their village
Stolypin wanted to peasants to move east and cultivate land privately
Stolypin was not a revolutionary, he was a reformer
He believed in a strong monarch
The successfulness of Stolypin's land reforms is controversial
This is because many peasants didn't want to leave their communal villages, opposed the idea of private property
He was disliked by so many because he supported the monarchy, while also fighting for reform. So both sides resented him
In 1911 Stolypin was assassinated by a 24-year old wealthy Jew

title: Russia at War
content:
Germany's Schlieffen Plan counted on Russian mobilization taking around 100 days while they dealt with France
German victory required a fast war
The Russian army was divided into separate divisions that didn't communicate
This was detrimental in the Battle of Tannenberg, where two armies were a few hundred km apart and the German division took advantage of this by going in between them and targeting one Russian army, the other Russian army couldn't help them due to lack of communication
Russia was economically immature in WW1
At the beginning of the war they had more soldiers than guns
They would have unarmed soldiers in the back that would pick up the weapons of dead soldiers
Russia lost Warsaw and land in Poland to Germany
In 1915 the Russo-German front stabilized, but not to the extent of the western front
Russian civilians were told all about the disasters of the Russian army
The Galician (Austro-Hungarian) front had enormous casualties on both sides, Austria became more reliant on Germany, and this destabilized Austria-Hungary
Distracted Germany from the western front

title: Toward the Catastrophe
content:
Despite Russia not being an economic power pre ww1, its currency was backed by a lot of gold
But as the war dragged on, Russia printed tons of unbacked Rubles leading to crazy inflation
Failures throughout WW1 made all parties distrust the Tsar
PM Sturmer was suspected of treason because of his German decent, other political figures made claims about treasonous activities without much evidence at the Duma meetings
Sturmer dismissed without any evidence of treason
Other countries gave opportunities for Russians to betray the country, but there was no evidence shows Russians responding
Rasputin's influence on the Queen became apparent to the public and high officials
This mattered because the Tsar usually followed Alexandra's advice
Rasputin was killed by Right wing monarchists
They believed his death would strengthen the monarchy
Rasputin was a peasant 
The Tsarist political motives backfired because the public distrusted the monarchy even more because it was seen as high ups manipulating the Tsar
Undermined the Tsar's authority, and the murder of a peasant (Rasputin) by high officials led to polarization
His murder became a symbol of high up corruption
Alexandra didn't initially believe his death
Nicholas II didn't seem to personally care for Rasputin's death
All took place in late 1916 to early 1917

title: February Revolution
content:
The winter of 1917 was notably cold
In late February the weather became milder and brought out the crowds
Crowds in Petrograd became especially violent
What solidified the revolution were the mutinous soldiers
Nicholas was away at the war effort in military headquarters
He believed this would strengthen public sentiment of the Monarchy
Because of this he was somewhat unaware of the serious upheaval in Petrograd
He ignored warnings from advisors
When Nicholas abdicated the Provisional government came about, which was formed by the Duma
The Provisional government now shared power with the Petrograd soviet, which had power over different aspects of the state
PG had authority over legislative things, while the Soviet controlled practical things like troops, railways, and communication
The Soviet had the more public trust
The Ispolkom was the council of the Soviet, which represented workers, and soldiers
The Soviet issued orders such as Order no. 1, which told soldiers to obey the Soviet
It is important that the Soviet took most of the power and authority over the Provisional government
The Soviet consisted of Socialist Revolutionaries, and Mensheviks
During these revolutionary times much violence occurred, particularly against people who seemed pro german
After Nicholas abdicated he went north to an estate where he was notably quiet and slept soundly, as if he enjoyed the burdens of leadership being lifted off of his shoulders
The Russian public was still adamant on winning the war
It is notable how fast the Revolution happened, on Feb. 25 Nicholas gave his last order of any significance, and by March 1 Order No. 1 had been issued by the Soviet

title: Lenin and the Origins of Bolshevism
content:
Lenin associated himself completely with the party, had no external public image
Born into a well of bureaucratic family
Lenin's older brother was a terrorist in 1887
In his youth he showed no interest in public affairs
Officially he was always a Marxist from birth, but this is false
It was believed around the turn of the century, that in order to turn Russia into a communist state that there would first have to be a lengthy interlude of capitalism, Lenin agreed with this
Lenin saw the bourgeoisie as a class enemy to the proletariat (the working class)
Lenin was similar to Robespierre, believing that he is "the people" in a representative sense of course
The Social Democratic Party was founded in 1898
Consisted of Mensheviks and Bolsheviks
The Bolsheviks officially split off from in 1912
In 1897 Lenin was exiled for leading revolutionary movements back when the Tsar still had power
In 1900 at the end of his siberian exile he self exiled to western europe to avoid persecution and work on his revolutionary papers. He came back for the 1905 revolution
In 1907, after the revolution had died down Lenin again self exiled in western Europe until 1917
The Social Democrats didn't play much of an important role in the 1905 revolution
Among the SD's the Bolsheviks had less support and money
The Bolsheviks resorted to crime for funding their cause, also their members were effectively full time workers for the party
Most of this crime died down after 1910
Some of the revolutionary causes during the war were effectively pro-german, especially the Bolsheviks
The Germans allowed Bolshevik leaders to travel through Germany during the war

title: The Bolshevik Bid for Power
content:
The October Coup was not a revolution in the sense that the February Revolution was
The October Coup was a small group of conspirators, who gained power via methods similar to those used in war
The Provisional Government was extremely pro-allied forces, so much that some Germans thought the February Revolution was orchestrated by Brits
Gained power through destruction and even extermination of political opponents, leaving themselves to take power
War by these means were between classes, fought vertically, not horizontally
This was all classified as a "class war"
Lenin followed Marx's ideas of destroying the current system and building anew, instead of the old ways of revolution where the institutions and positions stayed the same, but the personnel was the only things changed
These old practices of revolution left room for counter revolutionaries
Lenin saw the Russian Revolution as the first of many global revolutions, Russian just happening to be the first candidate
Lenin was very secretive about this intention and many other of his intentions, this was to keep his opponents in the dark
Lenin had a very high understanding of mass psychology and the mentality of crowds
Lenin won power by first breaking the spirit if those in his way, the mass street events making his ascension to power seem inevitable
